questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with painless lymphadenopathy and occasional fever. A biopsy shows diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
• R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, and Prednisone) is the standard first-line therapy for DLBCL, offering curative outcomes in 60-65% of patients.
  • Rituximab monotherapy is not sufficient for aggressive lymphomas like DLBCL.
  • High-dose methotrexate is used in CNS prophylaxis for high-risk cases but not as the primary therapy.
  • CAR-T cell therapy is reserved for relapsed/refractory cases after multiple lines of treatment.

Key Takeaways:

  • R-CHOP remains the cornerstone treatment for newly diagnosed DLBCL.
  • CAR-T cell therapy is emerging for relapsed/refractory DLBCL.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of gastric MALT lymphoma reports dyspepsia. Which infectious agent is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• Helicobacter pylori infection is strongly associated with gastric MALT lymphoma and can lead to regression of the lymphoma with antibiotic therapy.
  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with Burkitt lymphoma and aggressive NHLs in immunocompromised patients.
  • HTLV-1 is linked to adult T-cell lymphoma, especially in Japan and the Caribbean.
  • Campylobacter jejuni is associated with certain intestinal NHL subtypes but not gastric MALT lymphoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • H. pylori is a significant causative factor in gastric MALT lymphoma and is often treated with antibiotics.
  • Other infections associated with NHL include EBV and HTLV-1.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and a rapidly enlarging abdominal mass. Biopsy confirms Burkitt lymphoma. Which genetic translocation is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• t(8;14) translocation involves the MYC gene and the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus, a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • t(14;18) is associated with follicular lymphoma involving BCL2.
  • t(11;14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma involving cyclin D1 (CCND1).
  • t(2;5) is characteristic of anaplastic large cell lymphoma involving ALK.

Key Takeaways:

  • Burkitt lymphoma is characterized by MYC gene translocations, typically t(8;14).
  • This lymphoma is highly aggressive but responsive to prompt chemotherapy.

choices.text: Suggests aggressive disease and correlates with high tumor metabolism
Is used solely for diagnosis and not for prognosis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) undergoes a PET-CT. The scan shows multiple FDG-avid lymph nodes. What is the significance of FDG avidity in this context?
questions.solution:
• FDG avidity on PET-CT is common in aggressive lymphomas like DLBCL, reflecting high metabolic activity.
  • Low-grade lymphomas typically show lower FDG uptake.
  • PET-CT is not specific to lymphoma and can be used to assess response to therapy and guide prognosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • PET-CT is crucial for staging, response assessment, and prognosis in aggressive lymphomas.
  • FDG uptake correlates with tumor aggressiveness and can guide management.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Burkitt lymphoma requires immediate initiation of treatment due to its rapid progression.
Reason (R): Burkitt lymphoma has a high proliferation rate with a doubling time of less than 24 hours.
questions.solution:
• Burkitt lymphoma is one of the fastest-growing human tumors with a doubling time of less than 24 hours, necessitating urgent treatment.
  • The rapid progression is due to the high proliferation rate, which supports the need for immediate initiation of combination chemotherapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Burkitt lymphoma is a medical emergency due to its aggressive nature.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are critical for improving outcomes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with painless lymphadenopathy in the neck and mediastinum. Biopsy shows classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL) with Reed-Sternberg cells positive for CD15 and CD30. Which imaging modality is preferred for staging in this patient?
questions.solution:
• PET/CT is the preferred imaging modality for staging Hodgkin lymphoma due to its accuracy in detecting nodal and extranodal disease.
  • CT scans are less specific as they do not provide metabolic activity data.
  • MRI is useful for CNS involvement but not routine for HL staging.
  • Ultrasound has limited use in staging HL.

Key Takeaways:

  • PET/CT provides comprehensive staging information and is crucial for treatment planning in HL.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with newly diagnosed Hodgkin lymphoma reports weight loss, fever, and night sweats. What is the term used to describe these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• B symptoms include unexplained weight loss, fever, and night sweats and are significant in staging and prognostication of Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Paraneoplastic symptoms can occur in various cancers but are not specific to HL.
  • Pel-Ebstein fever is a rare cyclical fever associated with HL.
  • Systemic symptoms are a general term not specific to HL.

Key Takeaways:

  • B symptoms are crucial for staging and impact treatment decisions in Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with Hodgkin lymphoma is treated with ABVD chemotherapy. What is a significant late complication associated with this treatment?
questions.solution:
• Late complications of Hodgkin lymphoma treatment include secondary malignancies, especially solid tumors and leukemia, due to radiation and chemotherapy.

Option C: Infertility is common in men treated with alkylating agents but is rare with ABVD.

Option D: Hypothyroidism is associated with neck radiation.

Option A: Neuropathy is less common but may occur due to vinblastine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Secondary malignancies are a major concern in HL survivorship, particularly in those treated with radiation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male diagnosed with advanced-stage classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL) receives ABVD chemotherapy. What is the role of interim PET/CT scans in his management?
questions.solution:
• Interim PET/CT scans after 2-3 cycles of chemotherapy help assess response and guide further treatment decisions in HL.
  • PET/CT is not used for diagnosis but for staging and monitoring.
  • Detection of metastasis is part of initial staging.
  • Biopsy site selection is usually based on clinical findings.

Key Takeaways:

  • Interim PET/CT is crucial for response assessment and may alter the course of treatment.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Reed-Sternberg cells are diagnostic for classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
Reason (R): Reed-Sternberg cells express CD15 and CD30, which aid in diagnosis.
questions.solution:
• Reed-Sternberg cells are the hallmark of HL and are characterized by CD15 and CD30 positivity, aiding in the diagnosis.
  • These markers help differentiate HL from other lymphomas.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells with CD15 and CD30 is critical for HL diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma is considered for salvage therapy. What is the next step if he responds well to salvage chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Autologous stem cell transplantation is the standard curative approach for patients responding to salvage chemotherapy in relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Allogeneic transplantation is considered if autologous fails.
  • Maintenance therapy is used in specific cases, usually post-transplant.

Key Takeaways:

  • High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplant is the mainstay in relapsed HL with favorable response to salvage therapy.

choices.text: 4 cycles of ABVD followed by radiation therapy

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with early-stage favorable Hodgkin lymphoma (stage IIA) undergoes treatment. What is the recommended standard of care?
questions.solution:
• Combined-modality therapy (4 cycles of ABVD followed by radiation) is the standard for early-stage favorable Hodgkin lymphoma, reducing relapse rates.
  • ABVD alone is considered in certain cases, but combined therapy offers a better progression-free survival.
  • Radiation alone is insufficient for systemic disease control.

Key Takeaways:

  • Combined-modality therapy remains the gold standard in early-stage favorable HL to minimize recurrence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with Hodgkin lymphoma has a negative interim PET/CT scan after 2 cycles of ABVD. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• A negative interim PET/CT suggests a good response, allowing continuation of the current regimen (ABVD) to complete 6 cycles.
  • Intensifying to BEACOPP is not needed with a negative PET scan.
  • Radiation is not used alone in systemic disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Negative interim PET/CT supports continuing the current chemotherapy regimen in Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with HIV-associated classical Hodgkin lymphoma shows positive Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) markers. What is the implication of EBV positivity in this patient?
questions.solution:
• EBV positivity in HIV-associated Hodgkin lymphoma is linked with worse outcomes and reflects a higher burden of immunosuppression.
  • This association necessitates close monitoring and possibly more aggressive therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • EBV positivity is a poor prognostic marker in HIV-associated Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female undergoes treatment for classical Hodgkin lymphoma and develops hypothyroidism. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Neck radiation commonly causes hypothyroidism due to damage to the thyroid gland.

Option A: Chemotherapy regimens like ABVD have minimal thyroid effects.

Option C: PD-1 inhibitors can cause thyroid dysfunction but are less likely in this scenario.

Option D: Steroids do not directly cause hypothyroidism.

Key Takeaways: Thyroid monitoring is crucial for patients receiving neck radiation in Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Match the Lymphoma Subtypes with their Chromosomal Translocations
questions.solution:
• Burkitt Lymphoma: Characterized by the t (8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene.
  • Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Associated with t (11;14), leading to overexpression of cyclin D1.
  • Follicular Lymphoma: Commonly involves the t (14;18) translocation with the BCL2 gene.
  • Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma: Frequently associated with BCL6 rearrangements such as t (3;14).

questions.text: Match the Lymphoma Treatments with Their Specific Indications
questions.solution:
• ABVD: Standard regimen for early-stage classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • R-CHOP: Standard treatment for DLBCL.
  • Brentuximab Vedotin: CD30-directed antibody-drug conjugate used in relapsed/refractory HL.
  • Escalated BEACOPP: Used for advanced-stage HL, especially with PET-positive findings.

questions.text: Match the Diagnostic Markers with the Type of Lymphoma
questions.solution:
• CD15, CD30: Diagnostic markers for classical Hodgkin lymphoma, particularly Reed-Sternberg cells.
  • CD10, BCL6: Common markers in Burkitt lymphoma.
  • CD19, CD20, BCL2: Markers associated with follicular lymphoma, reflecting B-cell lineage and anti-apoptotic properties.
  • CD3, CD4, PD-1: Markers typical for Peripheral T-cell lymphomas.

questions.text: Match the Common Risk Factors with the Associated Lymphoma Types
questions.solution:
• H. pylori Infection: Strongly associated with gastric MALT lymphoma.
  • HTLV-1 Infection: Leads to Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, common in endemic areas like Japan and the Caribbean.
  • EBV: Frequently seen in classical Hodgkin lymphoma, especially in immunocompromised settings.
  • HIV Infection: Increases risk for aggressive NHLs, including Burkitt lymphoma.
